question: Question_09_(c)
statement:
Let

\[\displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{  and  }\quad g: B \to A\]

be functions so that \emph{g} â\emph{f} is a surjective function.

Prove or disprove that \emph{f} â\emph{g} must be surjective.
sols:
The example that we constructed in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (b)}{part
(b)} showed a case where the function \emph{f} is not surjective and so
it cannot be possible for $f \circ g$ to be surjective either. For
example, in that case, no negative number is in the image of the
function \emph{f} and so no negative number can be in the image of
$f \circ g$ either.
hints:
Working on
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (a)}{part
(a)} and
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (b)}{part
(b)} definitively helps.

In your example in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH220/April 2011/Question 09 (b)}{part
(b)} \emph{f} was not surjective. Can $f \circ g$ possibly be surjective
then?
